1. A 250-word version

Title: Bilateral Remote Ischemic Conditioning in Children: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Background: This study aimed to evaluate the cardioprotective effects of bilateral remote ischemic preconditioning (RIPC) in young children undergoing surgery for tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) or ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Methods: In a double-blind, randomised controlled trial conducted at Birmingham and Leeds Children's Hospitals, UK, 120 children aged 3 to 36 months were randomised 1:1 to receive RIPC or a sham procedure. The primary outcome was the area under the curve (AUC) for high-sensitivity troponin-T in the first 24 hours post-surgery, analysed by intention-to-treat. Randomisation was performed using a secure online system with allocation concealment, and blinding was maintained for patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Results: From October 2016 to December 2020, 120 children were randomised: 60 to RIPC and 60 to control. The primary outcome showed a higher AUC for troponin-T in the RIPC group (mean: 70.0 ± 50.9 μg/L/h) compared to controls (mean: 55.6 ± 30.1 μg/L/h) with a mean difference of 13.2 μg/L/h (95% CI, 0.5-25.8; P = .04). No significant differences were observed in secondary outcomes or myocardial metabolism. Adverse events were similar between groups.

Interpretation: Bilateral RIPC did not reduce myocardial injury and may be harmful in unstented TOF. Routine use of RIPC is not recommended for myocardial protection in pediatric cardiac surgery.

Trial registration: ISRCTN12923441
